channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cheering From the Den During a Virtual Convention
item.description: Some die-hard Democratic delegates long for an in-person event. “It feels so lonesome when you don’t have all the crowds,” said an 89-year-old convention veteran.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Rosalind Wyman’s house in Los Angeles, the Democratic National Convention is blaring from television sets in four rooms. “I have it so that I won’t miss anything,” she said.

item.title: ‘Finally the Country Sees Us’: Some Women of Color Cheer Harris’s Rise
item.description: In Kamala Harris, many women of color see a successful vice-presidential candidate standing atop a mountain of firsts — but also facing a gender and racial minefield.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch, Jennifer Medina and Evan Nicole Brown
item.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We want our leaders to make Black lives a priority and to shift the systems that do not serve us and were not made for us,” Krystina François said.

item.title: Reopening Florida Schools Is Likened to Military Operation
item.description: Gov. Ron DeSantis, faced with reluctance by local schools to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic, compared it to the campaign to get Osama bin Laden.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Stallings setting up her second-grade classroom at MacFarlane Park Elementary in Tampa, Fla. Most Florida schools must offer in-person instruction by the end of the month.

item.title: The California Wildfires in Pictures
item.description: Photographers are on the ground capturing the fast-moving fires that are spreading across the state.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Group at Center of Bannon Indictment Used Private Funds to Build Border Wall
item.description: The criminal charges were the latest twist for We Build the Wall, which had drawn praise from top Homeland Security officials while causing controversy over its construction methods.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: A section of the border barrier funded by the private group We Build The Wall under construction last year in Sunland Park, N.M.

item.title: Top Republican National Security Officials Say They Will Vote for Biden
item.description: In a letter released hours before Joe Biden is set to deliver his nomination acceptance speech, over 70 senior officials called President Trump “unfit to lead” and outlined their support for his opponent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Larry Downing/Reuters
item.media:description: Among the signatories are former officials like John Negroponte, left, the former director of national intelligence, and General Michael Hayden, who served as director of the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Agency.

item.title: MGM Remakes Orion Pictures to Tell More Inclusive Stories
item.description: The 36-year-old producer Alana Mayo will lead the division, which will release two or three films a year and focus exclusively on underrepresented filmmakers.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Aaron J. Thornton/Getty Images for Essence
item.media:description: “Who gets to say ‘yes’ is massively important,” said Alana Mayo, second from right, who will lead Orion Pictures.

item.title: New Measures Aim to Boost Vaccine Rates for Flu and Children’s Shots
item.description: Pharmacists may now vaccinate young children under a new federal emergency rule aimed at helping families who missed well-child visits during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Signs advertised free flu shots outside a drugstore in Manhattan this week.

item.title: Norman Carlson, Forceful Head of U.S. Prisons, Dies at 86
item.description: He created the model for today’s super-maximum security prisons and oversaw a near doubling of federal facilities. He also insisted on cleanliness and decent food.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: United States Penitentiary Administrative Maximum Facility
item.media:credit: Roger Strong/The New York Times
item.media:description: Norman Carlson, left, outside the federal prison in Danbury, Conn., in 1977. He instituted a federal policy of zero-tolerance for the abuse of prisoners by guards.

item.title: Trump Meets With Iraqi Leader Amid Negotiations Over U.S. Troop Levels
item.description: Prime Minister Mustafa al-Kadhimi’s visit to the White House is largely focused on negotiations, which started in May, on resetting the United States military mission in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with Mustafa al-Kadhimi, the prime minister of Iraq, in the Oval Office on Thursday, where Mr. Trump reiterated his desire to remove U.S. troops from the region.

item.title: Vacationing Israeli Teen Says She Was Gang-Raped, Shocking the Nation
item.description: One of the accused has said that as many as 30 men took part in the attack at a hotel in the Red Sea resort city of Eilat.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:credit: Artur Widak/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The teen was on a three-day trip to Eilat, a resort town in southern Israel.

item.title: Uber and Lyft Threaten to Shut Down in California
item.description: The companies, under legal pressure to reclassify their drivers as employees, said they would halt rides unless an appeals court gives them permission to continue.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uber and Lyft could suspend ride-hailing services throughout California on Thursday night.

item.title: The Phantom-Limb Democratic Convention
item.description: Milwaukee is the titular site of the Democratic National Convention, defined less by what is happening inside the Wisconsin Center than what is not.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michelle Obama’s pre-recorded speech played on a television inside the Wisconsin Center, where the Democratic National Convention was anchored this week.

item.title: Who Is David C. Williams? A Postal Service Overseer Who Resigned
item.description: Mr. Williams, who will testify before lawmakers about the U.S. Postal Service on Thursday, is expected to allege efforts by the Trump administration to undermine the agency.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: David C. Williams, the former Postal Service inspector general, has spent four decades in Washington providing oversight of federal agencies.

item.title: Stephen F. Williams, U.S. Appeals Court Judge, Dies at 83
item.description: A Reagan appointee, he served on the District of Columbia bench for three decades. He died of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: An ‘Unprecedented’ Effort to Stop the Coronavirus in Nursing Homes
item.description: Researchers are testing an experimental drug to halt sudden outbreaks. The trial may bring a new type of treatment for the virus.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heartland Health Care Center in Moline, Ill., was the first facility to participate in a large clinical trial of a drug that may protect residents from infection with the coronavirus.

item.title: More than 300 Fires Burning in California, including Solano, Napa, Sonoma Counties
item.description: Thursday: California in August has tested the limits of things that can go wrong at once. Also: Californians at the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: California Fires Live Updates: Thousands of Homes in Danger
item.description: Thousands of people have fled their homes amid a grueling heat wave, the coronavirus pandemic and air thick with smoke.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: This is the speech Biden has prepared for his entire life.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Courtland Wells for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will give the most important — and probably most surreal — address of his career to close out the final night of the Democratic National Convention.

item.title: Convention speakers celebrated women’s progress and noted there’s more to be made.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris, accepting the vice-presidential nomination, started her speech by making note of the anniversary of the 19th Amendment.

item.title: Trump phone calls add to lingering questions about Russian interference in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump knew of and discussed stolen Democratic emails at critical points late in his 2016 campaign for the White House, according to a Senate Intelligence Committee report.

item.title: Election concerns persist despite Louis DeJoy’s move to halt postal changes.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Hailey Fuchs, Kenneth P. Vogel and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: An election official dropped a voter’s mail-in ballot in an official drop box for Florida’s primary election in Doral, Fla., on Tuesday.

item.title: The Night of the Coalition
item.description: As Kamala Harris accepted the vice-presidential nomination, the voters who power the modern Democratic Party were the night’s focus.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris accepting the vice-presidential nomination in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: California vs. Ride-share Companies
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Don Emmert/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Lyft logo on the Nasdaq office screen in Times Square in New York last year.

item.title: Covid-19 News: Live Updates
item.description: Overburdened health care specialists are finding themselves on the front lines as schools reopen. India’s crisis is now spreading to the hinterlands along its southern coastline.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: For Japanese-Americans, Housing Injustices Outlived Internment
item.description: In 1945, thousands were released from internment camps. But they couldn’t return to the world they had left.
item.dc:creator: Bradford Pearson

item.title: School Nurses Are on the Coronavirus Front Lines. But Many Schools Don’t Have One.
item.description: Less than 40 percent of the nation’s schools had a full-time nurse before the pandemic, and there has been no national effort to hire more.
item.dc:creator: Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City hired more nurses after the city’s powerful teachers’ union said its members should not return to classrooms without a nurse in each school building.

item.title: Pediatric Doctors Group Apologizes for Racist Past Toward Black Physicians
item.description: The American Academy of Pediatrics recently joined other prominent medical organizations in confronting its history of discrimination.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Howard University, via U.S. National Library of Medicine
item.media:description: Dr. Roland B. Scott in the 1950s, during his time as a professor at Howard University in Washington.

item.title: 5 Things We Know About Flying Right Now
item.description: As passengers cautiously return to air travel, there are a few issues worth considering — from middle-seat policies to questions about virus transmission on airlines.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: The number of fliers passing through T.S.A. checkpoints has recently increased substantially since the pandemic began. Above, George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston.

item.title: Watch the Four Moments That Mattered on the Third Night of the D.N.C.
item.description: Two of our correspondents break down highlights from the Democrats’ first virtual convention.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris is joined by Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. after accepting the Democratic nomination for Vice President at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: DNC Schedule: Biden's Speech, Stream, Start Time
item.description: Joe Biden will finally take the stage Thursday night, as will several of his former primary opponents.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Biden joined Senator Kamala Harris after she accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi, Hillary Clinton, Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris Speak of Women's Vote Centennial at Democratic Convention
item.description: With Kamala Harris accepting her nomination, Nancy Pelosi, Hillary Clinton and others lauded the advancement of women in the political process, but said there was still much ground to be covered.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris of California accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president on Wednesday.

item.title: Immigrant ‘Dreamers’ in Search of a Job Are Being Turned Away
item.description: President Trump hopes to end DACA, which has granted employment authorization to thousands of young immigrants. Already, some large employers are refusing to hire them.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Rodriguez, a DACA recipient from Venezuela, received a rejection letter from one company after revealing his immigration status.

item.title: Democrats Have Their Doubts About Biden’s Bipartisan Bonhomie
item.description: Twelve years after he left the Senate, a President Biden would find a Capitol that is far more partisan and less open to deal-making than the one that shaped his views of legislating.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Zach Gibson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., who served in the Senate for 36 years, would arrive in the White House with the most high-level legislative experience of any president since Lyndon B. Johnson.

item.title: The Speech Joe Biden Has Been Preparing For His Entire Life
item.description: Some of it is familiar, after almost 50 years in politics. Some of it, like delivering such a momentous address to a virtual crowd, will be new.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck and Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Courtland Wells for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. will give the most important — and probably most surreal — address of his career.

item.title: ‘He Stiffed Our Party’: Bloomberg Doubts Resurface Before D.N.C. Speech
item.description: Michael Bloomberg’s appearance on the final night of the Democratic convention has reignited questions about his pledge to throw his fortune behind the effort to defeat President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael R. Bloomberg has transferred money to the Democratic Party and donated to progressive groups, but has not given directly to Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: Highlights From the Democratic National Convention: Night 3
item.description: Kamala Harris made history in accepting her official nomination for the vice presidency: She became the first woman of color to join a major party’s national ticket.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Dmitriy Khavin
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Nominate Harris for Vice President, as Obama Lashes Trump
item.description: Senator Kamala Harris became the first woman of color on a major party ticket, while former President Barack Obama condemned President Trump by name and issued a grim warning about the durability of American democracy.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: Watch Kamala Harris's DNC Speech: Full Video and Transcript of Accepting VP Nomination
item.description: In her vice-presidential acceptance speech on the third night of the Democratic National Convention, Ms. Harris said “there is no vaccine for racism” as she offered her vision for a more inclusive country.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic nomination for Vice President on Wednesday.

item.title: Thom Brennaman, Reds Announcer, Is Suspended for Homophobic Slur
item.description: The announcer, Thom Brennaman, apologized for his remarks, and said, “I don’t know if I’m going to be putting on this headset again.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: John Minchillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Thom Brennaman, broadcaster for the Cincinnati Reds, apologized on Wednesday night for using a homophobic slur. “I am very, very sorry and I beg for your forgiveness,” he said.

item.title: Full Transcript and Video of Obama's Speech at the DNC
item.description: The very future of our democracy is at stake, former President Barack Obama said Wednesday night, imploring voters to oust President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

item.title: Small-business owners speak on the coronavirus’s devastating economic toll.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio helped introduce a segment on the pandemic and the economy during the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday.
